climbs.name: Thumby Bloody Thumby
climbs.fa: Jim Hornibrook, Akiko Furukawa, Taska Sanford

content.description: Make a few height sensitive moves to access the higher of two horizontal cracks just right of a scary looking loose block. Traverse right making a few cruxy moves when the lower crack ends. Then ascend a flake which leads to the summit. Belay via small cams under a flake on the formation’s summit.
content.protection: Two each cam #2 and #3 are good for the traverse. A .75 protects the top of the flake and a few smaller cams are good for the belay.

climbs.name: Roach Motel
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Mike Lechlinski, January 1988

content.description: Fun and interesting climbing past several horizontal cracks that gains a thin crack near the top.
content.location:
Located 15 feet left of

Climb Of The Cockroaches

.

climbs.name: R.S. Chicken Choker
climbs.fa: Mike Lechlinski, Tom Gilje, Mari Gingery, Todd Gordon and Scott Cosgrove, January 1988

content.description: A strenuous and engaging thin crack over a roof on the south face of the crag. Expect hard pulls off thin jams on this short but enjoyable route.

climbs.name: Roach Roof
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Mike Lechlinski, Jan. 1988

content.description: a short but fun roof problem

This is the obvious line just left of

Classic Corner

which offers steep and continuous balance moves up an arete which is capped by a small roof. Well-protected with fun moves and a nice view of the surrounding desert. Gear belay and an easy walk-off from the top.

climbs.name: False Classic Corner (aka The Case Of The Missing Nolina)

content.description:
Left of

Classic Corner

(5.7) and across from the blocky

Cockroach Crag

is this left-facing corner system/ramp. Good jams on clean rock make this a worthy tick if in the area and a sunny location makes this a good route to do on those chilly afternoons, although there is little to no protection from the wind. Perhaps one star out of five.

This is the obvious double crack system on the top half of the right side of the southwest face of Cockroach Crag.

The bottom section is relatively rotten, but protects adequately if you avoid the really loose stuff.

The double crack system is wonderful, straight-on, solid, well-protected hands.  Like many climbs, it's main crime is being too short.
content.protection:
Small cams or (preferably, since the rock isn't all that solid) tricams for the horizontals, up through a #2 Camalot for the cracks.

Small cams/tricams up through #3 Camalot for an anchor on top, depending on where you choose to build it.

Walk off to the northeast and down the gully on either side of the rock.

climbs.name: Climb Of The Cockroaches
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon, Mike Lechlinski, Mari Gingery, Cyndie Bransford, and Jennifer Wonderly, Jan. 1988

content.description: a steep route with some fun face/flake moves, but some large loose holds detract from the experience

Not much ambiguity here.  It's a clean, right angle, right facing dihedral, into a roof, which you pass with the handcrack on the right.

There is (or was, as of January 1, 2003) a loose block a few feet up in the crack.  You can choose to either crank on it, thereby changing the lower section of the climb and possibly injuring your belayer, or carefully avoid it, thereby leaving the climb intact.  I recommend the latter.  :)

There's a downclimb to climber's left.
content.protection: This corner pretty much soaks up gear; you can sink as much of a standard rack into it as you want, but won't need anything particularly large (up to a #2 Camalot is fine) or small (leave the micros behind.)  Save a handful of pieces for the anchor on top.
